Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The stability of Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst at 280,325 and 350 ºC. 120 mg catalyst was loaded for each condition tested. The N2:H2 ratio was maintained at 1:3 with a WHSV of 60000 mLst gcat −1 h−1 and pressure was 10 barg. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Ammonia synthesis rate with the change of time on stream. Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst involved milling CoCl2 and LiH, washing, and drying during the synthesis whereas Co-LiH(pur) only involved the milling of commercial Co and LiH. Reaction condition: Temperature, 350 ºC; pressure, 10 barg; stoichiometric reactant ratio was maintained with WHSV, 60000 mLst gcat −1 h−1, and 120 mg catalyst was loaded for each case. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The stability of the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst with the change of milling time and washing frequency. Reaction condition: With 120 mg of catalyst loading, all the catalysts were tested at 350 ºC, 10 barg pressure, and 60000 mLst gcat −1 h−1 WHSV. The reactant gas ratio was maintained at 1:3 for N2:H2. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 X-ray diffractograms for Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst at various reaction conditions. a) Fresh catalyst, b, and c) Activated catalyst where the reaction was performed at 20000 mLst and 60000 mLst gcat −1 h−1 WHSV, d) Nitride sample was prepared by flowing N2 gas through Co-LiH(rxn) bed at 20 barg for 24 h, e) Spent catalyst stopped NH3 production after 6 days, and f) Sample collected after the TPD test on spent catalyst samples. Note: 120 mg catalyst was loaded for b, c, d, e, and f and the reaction was conducted at 350 ºC for all samples. Data was collected using a zero-background holder and with Kapton film on top of the samples. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Structural characterization of Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst by SEM where images are for; a) activated, and b) spent samples. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM images of (a) fresh Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst and (b,c) high-resolution images showing d-spacing of (b) Co(111), and (c) LiOH(110) in the fresh sample. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 TEM images of spent Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst showing, a) particles at lower magnification; b) d-spacing obtained from the spent catalyst is mentioned in the image as ‘d’. The nearest d-spacing resembling Co(111) crystallite. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Ar-TPD was performed on activated and spent Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst. 120 mg catalyst was loaded in each case. For the activated catalyst, after collecting a data point, the reactor was stopped and cooled down to room temperature while N2 and H2 still flowing. For the spent catalyst, the reaction continued until no detectable synthesis rate was observed. For the TPD test, Ar was introduced at the flow rate of 60 mL/min and continued until the temperature reached 700 ºC, at 5 ºC min−1 ramp for both cases. Fig. 9 Scheme 1 Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst deactivation steps. Small-sized particles initially help in balancing the generation of intermediates and the final product NH3. With the Co particle size growing bigger due to sintering, the production rate of intermediates (Li-N-H components) is hampered as well and the continuous NH3 production is affected as the generated Li-N-H starts accumulating instead of decomposing to facilitate NH3 production. Unraveling the deactivation mechanism of Co-LiH composite catalyst for ammonia synthesis at milder conditions Fouzia Hasan Nowrin Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation a Juliusz Warzywoda Visualization Data curation b Mahdi Malmali Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization a ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas Tech University Lubbock TX 79409 United States Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States b Materials Characterization Center, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States Materials Characterization Center, Texas Tech University Lubbock TX 79409 United States Materials Characterization Center, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States ⁎ Corresponding author. An efficient ammonia synthesis catalyst that operates under mild conditions has been a long-cherished goal in heterogeneous catalysis. The challenges associated with low-temperature ammonia synthesis arise from both the activation of inert N2 molecules and the presence of scaling relations between reactant dissociation and intermediate adsorption energies. Transition metals-metal hydride (TM-MH) composite catalysts have shown promise to overcome these challenges as both TM and MH actively participate in the reaction, enabling improved ammonia synthesis rates at lower temperatures (150 ºC). Considering this prospect, two types of Co-LiH catalyst were synthesized by ball-milling of precursors (CoCl2 and LiH- denoted as Co-LiH(rxn)) and pure components (Co and LiH- denoted as Co-LiH(pur)), and their catalytic activity was evaluated at several reaction conditions to investigate the stability for long-term operation. Co-LiH(rxn) was found to deactivate in less than 150 h whereas Co-LiH(pur) displayed a continuous production although the synthesis rate was 3 times lower than the former. Structural characterization techniques, such as XRD, SEM, and TEM were used, and it was found that Co metal in the FCC phase was primarily sintered due to its small particle size in the fresh catalyst. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) test on the spent Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst also displayed an ammonia release profile similar to that of LiNH2 decomposition, which confirms the presence of ammonia in the spent catalyst structure. Hence, another major finding is speculated that irreversible ammonia absorption by LiH at the target ammonia reaction conditions contributes to the deactivation of the catalyst and the formation of intermediate compounds that are required for continuous ammonia generation in this composite catalyst. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ammonia synthesis Mild condition Composite catalyst Sintering Metal hydride Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia plays a vital role as a fundamental ingredient in producing synthetic fertilizer, which is essential for supporting global food production [1]. It is also increasingly recognized as an attractive energy carrier, carbon-free liquid fuel, and hydrogen source due to several key aspects [2–5], such as the high hydrogen content and energy density of ammonia, adequate supply chain and storage infrastructure, ease of transportation, and highly optimized production at scale [6]. The current industrial ammonia production heavily relies on the well-established Haber-Bosch (HB) process, which requires high temperatures and pressure (above 400 ºC and 100 bar). More than 90% of ammonia production worldwide is via the HB process where the plants produce ammonia at large scales (1000–2500 tonne/day) to benefit from the economy of scale [7,8]. Currently, 96% of the required hydrogen is sourced from fossil fuels (natural gas and coal) [9], hence, ammonia production contributes to 1–2% of global CO2 emissions and is known to be the largest energy consumer in the chemical industry [10,11]. Furthermore, ammonia transportation from production plants to the point of use adds more energy burden and CO2 emission in the whole supply chain of the ammonia fertilizer. The century-old HB process is optimized with energy efficiencies close to the thermodynamic limits [12]. Alternative ammonia production processes that have the potential to reduce energy consumption and CO2 emission, such as electrochemical and photocatalytic ammonia synthesis are still in the early stage of development [13]. Hence, pathways that can alleviate reaction temperature and pressure requirements, using renewable feedstock, and intensifying the thermocatalytic HB process are being sought to supply the increasing demand in the agriculture and energy sector [14–20]. Reaction temperature majorly controls the synthesis rate, and pressure primarily influences the single-pass conversion. To improve the sustainability of the HB process for small-scale green manufacturing, a catalyst that can operate at more moderate conditions has been always pursued - one that can effectively lower the reaction temperature while maintaining a reasonable reaction rate under moderate pressure. The catalyst plays a vital role in the process of ammonia production. After the discovery of the first nitrogen fixation catalyst by Haber, it was first Mittasch who conducted a systematic study exploring over 2500 catalysts in search of a catalyst that can achieve reasonable rates at lower temperatures. Among the catalysts explored, Iron(Fe)-based catalyst emerged as the most promising candidate for industrial applications, which is still being used in modern plants [21]. On the other hand, the development of promoted Ruthenium(Ru)-based catalysts marked a significant advancement as Ru exhibited better activities when operating at low pressure within the temperature range of 300–400 °C. Over the past two decades, numerous Ru-based novel catalysts have been reported that surpass the performance of the benchmark Ru-Cs/MgO catalyst. This progress showcases the potential of Ru over other elements for ammonia synthesis [22]. However, the cost of Ru metal restricts its widespread adoption in industrial-scale ammonia synthesis plants [23]. Therefore, there is a significant interest in exploring alternative catalysts that can deliver comparable or even superior performance compared to Fe and Ru, but at lower pressure. Theoretical exploration in the search for a catalyst adaptable to mild conditions suggests the prospect of transition metals (TM) in developing new catalysts but points out the existence of scaling relation in activation and adsorption energies which hampers the production in the long run [24,25]. Recently, Wang et al. reported a series of composite catalysts prepared from 3d-TM and metal hydride (MH – e.g., LiH) that were able to circumvent the scaling relation [26]. All the synthesized catalysts were capable of producing ammonia at a distinctively higher rate in comparison with benchmark Ru and Fe-based catalysts. Among the catalysts tested, Fe-LiH, and Co-LiH displayed relatively high ammonia synthesis rates at temperatures as low as 150 ºC. The proposed reaction mechanism for the TM-LiH catalyst is suggested to involve three steps where nitrogen is activated by TM and then transferred to nearby LiH sites forming Li-N-H compounds. Other MHs have also been utilized in the synthesis of the composite catalyst, and when supported, the combination has shown excellent performance in ammonia synthesis reactions [27]. Further investigation into this class of composite catalyst revealed a synergistic effect between the active sites, which facilitates ammonia synthesis at low temperatures, regardless of the type of TM [28,29]. Understanding the structure sensitivity of the catalytic reactions is necessary in order to relate the structural properties with the optimum activity [30]. Boudart suggested the dependence of the kinetics of some of the chemical reactions on the size and structure of the active catalysts [31]. Ammonia synthesis was found to be structure-sensitive for Fe- and Ru-based catalysts [32–34]. For better catalytic performance, smaller particles are preferable as they would provide a higher active surface area. TM-MH composite catalyst synthesis technique involves ball-milling for better mixing and alloying. During ball-milling, the catalyst particles undergo deformation, leading to a size reduction that may fall within the nanoparticle size range. This size reduction maximizes the interfacial contact between the active materials, which can facilitate the continuous production of ammonia [29]. Although advantageous, reducing the size of TM and LiH in the composite catalyst can introduce challenges like particle agglomeration, which has not been studied yet; knowing that ammonia synthesis catalyst is structure sensitive, it is imperative to understand the interactions of TM and LiH in the composite catalyst. Although exploring more active catalysts at milder conditions is critical, the long-term stability of a catalyst should also be carefully investigated. This is why such a test is a key criterion in catalyst development for industrial applications [30]. TM-MH composite catalysts were evaluated for their stability but these tests were limited to up to 30 h [26,27,35]. The reported stability test for the TM-MH catalysts is relatively short in order to properly investigate catalyst stability performance [36–38]. Moreover, no detailed discussion was found regarding the structural changes in the TM-MH catalyst that occurred during the reaction. The discussion made was limited to mentioning the necessity of keeping catalyst sizes small to allow the enhanced synergistic effect of MH on TM. In one study, when the TM-MH catalyst was tested in a chemical looping ammonia synthesis process, the unstable nature was observed and reported [39]. Deactivation of the catalyst was attributed to the elemental segregation in the composite catalyst structure, which was partially addressed by ball-milling the spent catalyst. Nonetheless, no detailed structural analysis was provided to justify the claim. Given the immense promise of TM-MH catalyst for ammonia synthesis under milder conditions, a systematic analysis of the composite catalyst is required to further shed light on the reasons that led to catalyst deactivation – which is the objective of this report. We studied the stability of TM-MH composite catalyst for ammonia synthesis under milder conditions. Co-LiH catalyst was considered as a representative TM-MH and synthesized from both its precursors (CoCl2 and LiH) or directly from the pure constituents (Co and LiH). The catalytic activity tests were performed at different temperatures, pressure, and flow rates. Furthermore, long-term activity tests were also carried out at specific temperatures and pressures that were continued until no ammonia could be detected in the reactor outlet. Several structural characterizations were employed to identify the potential causes that led to the composite catalyst instability. Temperature-programmed desorption of the spent catalyst along with physisorption tests revealed the structural evolution of the ball-milled composite catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The catalyst was prepared following the method described elsewhere [26]. In brief, to prepare the cobalt-based composite catalyst, cobalt chloride (CoCl2, Alfa Aesar, 97%) and lithium hydride (Sigma Aldrich, 95%) were mixed with a 1:7 molar ratio in a zirconia grinding jar inside the glove box. The mixture was then ball-milled for four hours at 250 rpm in a Retsch planetary ball-mill (PM 100) with the following reaction proceeding: CoCl2 + 7LiH➔ Co-5LiH + 2LiCl + H2. The ball-milled product was washed with tetrahydrofuran (THF, Sigma Aldrich, HPLC grade) three times followed by vacuum filtration. Finally, cobalt-lithium hydride (Co-5LiH) was vacuum-dried for 12 h. In this work, the Co: LiH molar ratio was maintained at 1:5, and samples prepared using this method are denoted as Co-LiH(rxn). Another set of catalysts was prepared by ball-milling pure cobalt (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%, metal basis) with lithium hydride with a 1:5 molar ratio. The preparation of this catalyst did not involve washing and drying. This sample is denoted as Co-LiH(pur). 2.2 Activity test Typically, 120 mg of catalyst was loaded into a stainless steel reactor (I.D. 6.4 mm). The catalyst bed was secured on both sides using quartz wool. The reactor was then placed in a tube furnace that controls the reactor temperature. Catalyst samples were activated with a synthesis gas mixture of H2-N2 gas (3:1 ratio) while the furnace temperature ramped from room temperature to 400 ºC at 1 ºC min−1. The temperature was ramped down to a predetermined reaction temperature after being held at 400 ºC for 5 h. A total gas flow rate of 120 mLst min−1 was maintained to keep the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) in the vicinity of 60000 mLst gcat −1 h−1, which ensured operating conditions far from the equilibrium. The reactor effluent was directed to a 6 mM sulfuric acid solution. The ammonia synthesis rate was calculated based on the conductivity changes measured by a conductivity meter (Oakton CON 450). The calibration curve relating the conductivity and ammonia production is provided in Figure S1 of the Supplementary Information (SI) section. Catalyst samples were handled in a glovebox (Plas Labs, Inc™) equipped with humidity and oxygen detectors. Stability tests were conducted under similar conditions but for more than 150 h. These stability tests aimed to evaluate the lifespan and durability of the catalyst under reaction conditions while monitoring the ammonia production over time. 2.3 Characterization Catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using Rigaku Ultima III and Miniflex II. Difractograms were collected at room temperature. Samples were crushed and loaded either on a zero background sample holder followed by covering with Kapton film or in the capillary sample holder. The analysis was conducted for 2θ in the range of 10º and 90º using CuKα radiation (λ=0.154 nm), with a scan speed of 0.02º (capillary holder) or 5º (zero background holder) per minute. The most intense peak for cobalt (2θ = 44.3º) was used in the Debye-Scherrer equation to calculate the crystallite size. D = k λ β cos θ where D is the crystallite size, λ is the dimensionless shape factor, β is the line broadening of the full width at half-maximum of the peak intensity, and θ is the Bragg angle. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using a PHI 5000 VersaProbe II Hybrid photoelectron spectrometer. The instrument was fitted with a monochromatic Al-Kα source with photon energy at 1486.6 eV. Calibration of the XPS binding energy was accomplished using the C1s peak at 284.8 eV originating from adventitious carbon. To understand the morphology of the catalyst samples, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected using a Hitachi S-4300 field emission scanning electron microscope. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy was performed to obtain elemental distribution in different catalyst samples. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken by Hitachi H-9500. The instrument was operated at 300 kV to obtain the particle size distribution and d-spacing. Textural parameters of the catalyst samples were acquired by nitrogen physisorption in a Micromeritics 3Flex adsorption analyzer. All samples were degassed under vacuum at 200 ºC for 16 h before the measurements. Temperature-programmed decomposition (TPD) tests were performed in the same reactor used for the activity tests. Catalyst samples were heated from room temperature to 700 °C at a 5 °C min−1 ramp while flowing 60 mLst min−1 Argon (Ar). The reactor effluent was directed to an online mass spectrometer (ThermoStar® GSD 350 T) which analyzed and recorded the gas mixture signals (H2 at m/z=2, N2 at m/z=28, and NH3 at m/z=16 & 17). In this study, the catalyst samples are denoted corresponding to different stages of their use in the reaction experiments. The term "fresh" refers to catalysts that are synthesized and have not yet been tested. The term "activated" refers to the samples that are activated and actively produce ammonia for at least 5 h. "Spent" catalysts are activated and utilized in the ammonia synthesis reaction until the production of ammonia ceases (deactivated). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Co-LiH(rxn) activity The catalytic activity of Co-LiH(rxn) was evaluated at different reaction conditions by varying temperature, pressure, and flow rate. As displayed in Fig. 1a, the rate of ammonia production for the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst exponentially increased with increasing the reaction temperature from 230 to 350 ºC. In comparison to the previous report, the catalyst synthesized for this work exhibited comparable synthesis rates at the target temperature range [26], with a slight difference at temperatures below 320 ºC. The prospect of Co-LiH is more significant when compared to an industrial Fe-based catalyst (Ammomax 10-RS). No ammonia was detected in the acid trap solution for industrial Fe-based catalysts below 305 ºC. The ammonia synthesis rate at 350 ºC was 3290 μmolNH3 gcat −1 h−1 for the industrial Fe catalyst, whereas the ammonia synthesis rate exceeded 11600 μmolNH3 gcat −1 h−1 for Co-LiH(rxn) at similar reaction conditions. The Arrhenius plot (Figure S2) was used to obtain the apparent activation energy of Co-LiH(rxn). Activation energies and the order of reaction with respect to ammonia for Co-LiH catalysts are reported in Table S1. The activation energy for the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst was found to be 82.1 kJ mol−1 (for 230–350 ºC). In comparison, the reported activation energy for the Co-LiH catalyst was 52.1 kJ mol−1 at the temperature range of 225–325 ºC [26]. This difference is primarily due to the difference in the performance of the catalysts at a lower temperature range (cf. Fig. 1a). The effect of WHSV and pressure on Co-LiH(rxn) activity was also investigated. Activity results, shown in Fig. 1b and c, confirm the absence of external mass transfer limitation in our kinetic tests. The reaction order for ammonia is also an important parameter as it implies how strongly the intermediates and final product adsorb on the active sites. The higher the absolute value is, the stronger the bonding strength [40]. At 300 ºC, Wang et al. reported a reaction order of −1.2 for ammonia, whereas our results suggest a reaction order of −0.57 for Co-LiH(rxn) at 350 ºC, as summarized in Table S1 [26]. This indicates a weaker bond between the product ammonia and the catalyst at an elevated temperature, which is favorable for achieving improved synthesis rates. As displayed in Fig. 1c, the ammonia synthesis rate almost linearly increased with the pressure and reached 10300 μmol g−1 h−1 at 20 barg. The uprising activity trend with pressure suggests that the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst was not susceptible to poisoning by the reactant gases (N2 and H2) and could sustain the synthesis rates at higher pressure. It is worth noting that highly active catalysts proposed for low-temperature ammonia synthesis frequently suffer from hydrogen poisoning, in which active sites on the catalyst surface are majorly occupied by hydrogen atoms, thus blocking nitrogen atoms from interacting with the active sites [23]. As the increasing reaction pressure did not result in activity reduction, it can be deduced that Co-LiH(rxn) is not being poisoned by reactants. 3.2 Stability test The stability tests were conducted at three different temperatures for an extended period (150 h), and the activity data are illustrated in Fig. 2. The initial synthesis rates observed at three temperatures are comparable with the respective temperatures reported in Fig. 1a, further confirming the reproducibility of the synthesized catalyst. At all three temperatures, the synthesis rate dropped within 100 h, and ammonia could not be detected by acid trap after 140 h. The rate dropped only 17% in the first 50 h at 350 ºC, then increased for several hours, but eventually declined to zero within 150 h. At 325 ºC, a slight increase in the synthesis rate was observed and a maximum synthesis rate of 7500 μmol g−1 h−1 was sustained up to 100 h but later a decline in the synthesis rate was observed. The catalytic test at 280 ºC displayed a rather faster deactivation compared to other stability tests at different temperatures. Overall, the obtained results suggest the unstable nature of Co-LiH(rxn), independent of the operating temperature. The activity of the Co-LiH(pur) catalyst which was synthesized by ball-milling of pure LiH and Co was examined at 350 ºC and 10 barg, and the corresponding data is presented in Fig. 3. To provide a comparative analysis of synthesis rates, the stability test results of the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst are also provided in Fig. 3. While the Co-LiH(pur) catalyst exhibited lower activity, it demonstrated a more stable performance within 150 h; the synthesis rate only declined by 49% , indicating that Co-LiH(pur) inherits key structural characteristics that result in improved stability. We hypothesize that ball-milling of CoCl2 and LiH leads to the formation of a transient state of Co and LiH, with the crystals of these components at very close proximity - instead of forming distinct phases of Co and LiH. This transient state is believed to contribute to attaining higher activity for Co-LiH(rxn). XPS was conducted on fresh Co-LiH(rxn) and Co-LiH(pur) samples to identify the Co state in the catalysts and the results are illustrated in Figure S5. XPS of Co-LiH does not display any evidence regarding the transient state between Co and LiH. However, Wang et al. confirmed the presence of transient Li-Fe-H species in a similar type catalyst (Fe-LiH) by performing gas-phase optical spectroscopy[28]. The signals at ∼778 and ∼793 eV in Figure S5 are characteristic peaks of Co0 and confirm the presence of metallic Co in both catalyst samples. Figure S5 also displays four peaks associated with Co2p orbitals: the 2p3/2 peak, the 2p1/2 peak, and two strong satellite peaks at higher binding energies for both catalysts. The binding energy for the Co 2p3/2 peak was measured at 780.78 eV, and the energy difference between the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks was around 15.2 eV for Co-LiH(rxn), consistent with the characteristics of standard cobalt oxide (CoO) [41]. A similar difference was observed for Co-LiH(pur). The presence of both metallic and oxidized Co, thus, necessitates a thorough structural investigation coupled with robust in-situ techniques to prove the hypothesis of Li-Co-H formation and to identify the actual state of Co. Recently, several catalysts for ammonia synthesis have been reported that demonstrated remarkable long-term stability for more than 100 h while most of these catalysts were not being supported or promoted [37,42–48]. Even unsupported single-atom and bimetallic catalysts have been reported that exhibited long-term stable ammonia synthesis rates [45,47]. Hence, it was anticipated that the composite Co-LiH(rxn) would be stable for an extended period, independent of the presence of structural support. One possibility for the decline in the synthesis rate for Co-LiH(rxn) would be the presence of a poisoning compound, such as chlorides. The cobalt precursor used for the catalyst synthesis contained chlorine, and LiCl formed during the ball-milling. The poisoning effect of chloride ions (Cl-) on Ru-based ammonia synthesis catalysts is well-documented [49,50], and also reported for Fe-based catalysts [51]. To address this concern, before further evaluating the hypothesis of structural evolution of the TM-MH composite catalyst, the catalyst preparation procedure was modified to study whether the poisoning effect of leftover LiCl or unreacted CoCl2 should be taken into account. The ball-milling time was extended from 4 h to 8 h, and the washing frequency was changed between 3 and 6 times. The extended milling time not only reduced the particle size but also enhanced the likelihood of a more complete reaction between CoCl2 and LiH. Activity data presented in Fig. 4, however, shows an unexpected trend for the samples that were synthesized with a slight modification in catalyst synthesis. With the increase in the ball-milling time, the synthesis rate experienced a more rapid decline, and the catalyst failed to sustain the production rate beyond 100 h. Interestingly, when the catalyst was washed more than 3 times (regardless of the ball-milling time), it was deactivated more rapidly (within 70 h). According to this observation, it is unlikely that the deactivation of the catalyst can be related to the presence of chlorine. It is worth noting that elemental mapping of the catalysts prepared by 4 h and 8 h ball-milling demonstrated the presence of chlorine in all forms of Co-LiH(rxn) catalysts (Figure S3 and S4). Findings obtained thus far highlight the importance of comprehending the structural properties of the composite catalyst, which will be discussed in the following. 3.3 Structural characterization The deactivation of the composite Co-LiH(rxn) may be correlated with the structural characteristics of the catalyst at the ammonia synthesis conditions. A series of structural characterizations were conducted on fresh, activated, and spent catalysts derived from Co-LiH(rxn) and Co-LiH(pur) to further shed light on the mechanism of catalyst deactivation. XRD analysis was performed on Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst samples, and the diffractograms are displayed in Fig. 5. For LiH, three major LiH peaks are expected at 2θ = 38.2°, 44.5°, and 64.7°. However, in the fresh catalyst, no peaks resembling LiH were detected. One possibility is that LiH particles are too small and distributed evenly in the catalyst that they become XRD amorphous. To examine this, diffractograms of ball-milled only LiH were obtained, and compared with pure not ball-milled LiH as shown in Figure S6. Apparently, ball milling of LiH alters the peak intensities but does not eliminate the peaks entirely. Even when ball-milled LiH is subjected to the reaction conditions, relatively sharp peaks can be detected (cf. Figure S6). Therefore, the absence of LiH peaks in all forms of ball-milled Co-LiH(rxn) further supports our earlier finding that ball-milling in a reactive environment fuses Co and LiH and makes LiH almost amorphous or highly dispersed. Diffractograms indicate that the LiOH phase is evidently formed in all samples, while Li2O was detected in all other catalyst samples that experienced the reaction conditions. The source of Li-oxides might be from LiH as indicated by Figure S6 that exhibited both phases in pure LiH. Prior works reported that LiH can easily oxidize to form LiOH at atmospheric conditions or Li2O at elevated temperatures [52,53]. Hence, the presence of Li2O in thermally treated catalyst samples with higher intensity is expected. Co-LiH(pur) catalyst samples, both fresh and spent, also exhibited the presence of Li oxides (Figure S7). Both Co-LiH(rxn) and Co-LiH(pur) catalysts confirm the presence of Li-N-H compounds along with other Li-containing compounds, as displayed in Fig. 5 and S7, respectively,. To further investigate the influence of Li2O on the catalyst performance (poisoning vs. enhancing), we introduced Li2O by physically mixing it with Co-LiH(rxn) and Co-LiH(pur) catalysts and performed stability tests at the same reaction conditions stated in Fig. 3. As illustrated in Figure S8, with 17 wt% Li2O, Co-LiH(rxn) exhibited a 1.3 times increase in the initial ammonia synthesis rate compared to the rate for Co-LiH(rxn) displayed in Fig. 3, though the deactivation pattern was similar in both cases. This observation of initial rate improvement aligns with that of Tagawa et al., where the ammonia synthesis rate was improved by introducing Li2O with LiH [54]. However, the synthesis rate remained unchanged for the Li2O-containing Co-LiH(pur) catalyst while being in the stream for 180 h. This finding suggests that the stability and deactivation of the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst are most likely not influenced by the presence of LiOH and Li2O. Besides, the peak intensity of LiOH and Li2O did not change extensively in the spent catalyst in comparison with its activated states as seen in Fig. 5. If alterations occur in the crystallite size of LiOH and Li2O as a result of the ammonia synthesis reaction, such a change would be observed by the shifts in the width of their characteristic peaks in XRD diffractograms. Therefore, the changes in the crystallinity or growth of LiH crystallites or Li-oxides might not result in the deactivation of the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst. Since there were changes in the intensity of one of the peaks for Co metal observed in Fig. 5, we decided to collect another set of diffractograms for fresh, activated, and spent Co-LiH(rxn) samples using the capillary sample holder in order to analyze the crystallite size of Co. To increase the signal-to-noise ratio, diffractograms were obtained with a minimal scan speed, and the results are illustrated in Figure S9. Generally, Co peaks for the fresh, activated, and spent catalysts can be found at 2θ = 41.5º, 44.3º, 47.5º, 51.6º, and 75.9º. The peaks at 44.3º, 51.6º, and 75.9º correspond to the face-centered cubic (FCC) structure of cobalt (ICDD 04–001–3274) while other peaks belong to the hexagonal close-packed (HCP) Co phase (ICDD 04–001–3274). Compared to the FCC phase, the intensity for the HCP phase was lower in the composite catalyst as seen in Figure S9. The presence of the HCP Co phase in the catalyst structure holds significant importance for the ammonia synthesis reaction, as earlier studies have suggested that HCP Co exhibits higher activity in molecular nitrogen dissociation [55,56]. The lower concentration of HCP Co in Co-LiH(rxn) may impact the stability, and certainly that needs further validation. Co particles with a size below 20 nm predominantly form an FCC structure and the size above 40 nm belongs to HCP [57]. Higher intensity of FCC structure in fresh Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst, thus suggesting that the Co metal in the catalyst has size below 20 nm. Crystallite size analysis of Co metal also shows the size is less than 10 nm (c.f. Table 1) for fresh catalyst. Such small size makes Co nanoparticles more mobile, hence it makes it easier to agglomerate, leading to the formation of larger particles [57–60]. It is also worth noting that the stability tests were performed at temperatures above 300 ºC, which is close to Co Hüttig temperature (253 ºC) [61]. The Hüttig temperature governs the surface atom movement. At temperatures higher than Hüttig's temperature, Co crystallites gain mobility, resulting in the formation of larger particles through agglomeration, sintering, or recrystallization [62]. To confirm that Co agglomeration leads to sintering, the textural properties of the catalysts were evaluated by nitrogen physisorption. Sintering refers to the phenomenon where particles agglomerate and increase in size, leading to a decrease in the overall surface area of the catalyst. Table 1 summarizes the BET surface areas and pore volumes of Co-LiH(rxn) catalysts obtained from different stages of the reaction. The significant difference in the surface area among the fresh, activated, and spent catalysts, along with the observed crystallite growth of Co metal from XRD, serves as initial evidence for the agglomeration of Co particles. The decrease in the surface area for the activated catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst suggests that the available pores are collapsing and forming aggregates upon exposure of the catalyst to high temperatures for the activation and the reaction. To further investigate the agglomeration and catalyst deactivation behavior, structural characterization was conducted. The SEM images presented in Fig. 6 display the morphological features of Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst samples obtained from different stages of reaction. In Fig. 6a, the micrograph provides a visual representation of the distribution of fresh catalyst particles. These particles exhibit a wide range of sizes and shapes, indicating heterogeneity within the catalyst sample. While most of these particles are individually smaller than 10 μm, they tend to cluster together with neighboring particles. In contrast, the spent catalyst shown in Fig. 6b appears to have larger particles, with the size exceeding 10 μm. Furthermore, it is worth noting that in Fig. 6b, the spent catalyst displays particles with plate-like features containing sharp edges. A similar observation has been reported earlier for nitrogen-treated LiH [54]. This is in stark contrast to the fresh catalyst, which appears more granular in its overall appearance. Additionally, the micrograph in Fig. 6b, reveals a distinctively rigid and smooth appearance, resembling the melting and subsequent reconnection of particles. The comparison between the SEM images of fresh and spent catalysts likely suggests that the catalyst particles became agglomerated during the reaction process aligning with the physisorption test result. At similar magnifications, the SEM images provided for both the activated and spent samples of Co-LiH(pur) (Figure S10a and S10b) displayed a pattern similar to that observed in Co-LiH(rxn) samples. The significant differences between Figure S10a and S10b suggest that agglomeration also occurred under the reaction conditions for Co-LiH(pur) but might be at a slower rate as smaller particles adjacent to the big chunks were observed in Figure S10b. However, additional evidence is necessary to draw a conclusive determination on the agglomeration of catalyst particles, thus, elemental distribution was performed and reported in the next. Elemental distribution of Co-LiH(rxn) and Co-LiH(pur) catalysts are provided in Figures S3 and S11 of SI, respectively. Oxygen was found throughout the fresh and spent catalysts of both samples, which corroborates the presence of LiOH and Li2O, as observed in XRD patterns. Interestingly, despite the presence of oxygenous compounds in Co-LiH(pur), catalytic performance was stable for a longer period compared to Co-LiH(rxn). This evidence further confirms that the deactivation of the Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst is not related to the presence of oxygen or oxygenous compounds. However, chlorine was detected in both fresh and spent samples, as displayed in Figure S3a and S3b respectively. However, XRD of fresh, active, and spent Co-LiH(rxn) samples did not show any chlorine compounds, hence it is considered as highly dispersed while being presented at a small amount. While XRD analysis and SEM images provide evidence of particle agglomeration, and EDX confirms the presence of acclaimed poisonous compounds (oxygen and chlorine), nonetheless, the specific element or compound responsible for catalyst deactivation is yet to be identified. Therefore, TEM images are taken for Co-LiH(rxn) fresh and spent samples. Noticeably, the TEM of fresh catalyst in Fig. 7a is composed of dark nanoclusters without any distinct shape or particular size. To confirm that darker nanoclusters are composed of Co, high-resolution TEM images of fresh catalysts were acquired. The lattice spacing obtained from the darker spot was 0.202 nm, which corroborates the presence of metallic Co (111). Another lattice spacing in the vicinity of darker regions was also found with 0.258 nm. The closest match for 0.258 nm is the LiOH (110) plane, thus assigned to LiOH in Fig. 7c. Upon analyzing the TEM image of the spent catalyst presented in Fig. 8a, it is evident that Co particle size increased compared to the fresh catalyst. The lattice spacing identified in Fig. 8b confirms the presence of the Co (111) plane (0.202 nm). Evidently, Co particles in the spent sample are not present in nanoclusters as the fresh catalyst sample but rather unevenly distributed as huge chunks with particle sizes as large as 100 nm in the considered specimen area and segregated in different regions. The Co particles form larger crystallites (from XRD and TEM), indicating the agglomeration of Co nanoparticles, which leads to the growth of particles resembling sintering. 3.4 Thermal desorption test Sintering in the active metallic site of the catalyst is irreversible and if occurs, it is not possible to recover the activity of the catalyst by simple thermal treatment. To further confirm that sintering is the sole reason for catalyst deactivation, we treated the spent catalyst at a temperature higher than the reaction condition while flowing a nonreactive gas. This experiment provided additional information about other plausible aspects of catalyst deactivation. The desorption pattern illustrated in Fig. 9 shows the continuous release of ammonia from activated and spent catalyst samples. This thermal desorption test on the spent catalyst was performed multiple times to confirm the reproducibility, and additional results are illustrated in Figure S12. The mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) of 15 and 16 are also included to confirm that the intense peak is primarily associated with ammonia being released from the respective samples. In the case of the active catalyst, the ammonia release started at 100 ºC and stopped at around 500 ºC, exhibiting two distinct peaks. On the other hand, the spent catalyst shows a slightly higher onset temperature (150 ºC), followed by two large peaks between 500 and 600 ºC. The ammonia intensity peaks for the spent catalyst were larger, which suggests that a greater quantity of ammonia was absorbed in the spent catalyst. While comparing the obtained TPD profile of the spent catalyst, a resemblance to the decomposition of pure LiNH2 was observed [63]. This suggests the possible accumulation of Li-N-H compounds. It is widely accepted that doping metal hydrides with TMs can modulate the thermodynamic properties for lower-temperature hydrogen uptake and release [64]. We hypothesize that considering Co sintering and agglomerating within the catalyst, this is not an unlikely situation that thermodynamic properties of the Co-LiH catalyst change, which results in a higher activation energy barrier for the ammonia release – although this hypothesis needs further careful investigation. The observation from Ar-TPD on the active and spent catalyst samples corroborates with the XRD of the thermally treated catalyst, shown in Fig. 5b-f. Active catalysts irrespective of space velocity and spent catalyst exhibited the presence of Li-N-H compounds, identified as LiNH2 because Li2NH cannot be distinguished from the LiNH2 at the stated positions. The sample collected after Ar-TPD also exhibited the LiNH2 phase, meaning Li-N-H compounds are consistently present in the catalyst. LiNH2 is known as a potential hydrogen carrier and, thus, has been studied extensively [65]. Hydrogen releases from LiNH2 following the reaction below (R1). However, reaction R1 consists of two intermediate reactions, R2 and R3, where R2 is rate-limiting. This is because the reaction between LiH and ammonia, R3, to form LiNH2 and H2 is indeed thermodynamically favorable over a wide range of temperatures and proceeds rapidly, with a reported reaction time as short as 25 ms [66]. (R1) LiNH2 +LiH ↔ Li2NH+H2 ΔH= 44.5 kJ/mol (R2) 2LiNH2 →Li2NH+NH3 ΔH= 84.1 kJ/mol (R3) LiH+NH3 ↔ LiNH2+H2 ΔH= −43.1 kJ/mol The reaction mechanism described by Wang et al. highlights the hydrogenation of LiNH2 (reverse -R3) as one of the steps in the synthesis of ammonia using TM-LiH catalysts [26]. The hydrogenation reaction regenerates LiH and produces ammonia at low temperatures. However, it is worth emphasizing that when we take into account the enthalpy of the reaction, hydrogenation of LiNH2 reactions tends to be less favorable. Moreover, the decomposition of pure LiNH2 generates ammonia and Li2NH (R2), irreversibly. Hydrogenation of Li2NH can regenerate LiH and produce NH3, but the reaction can barely produce ammonia at the temperature considered for the mild condition ammonia synthesis (≈ 300 ºC) and requires high partial pressure of hydrogen [67]. The R2 and reverse-R3 are in favor of continuous ammonia production. In an ideal scenario, the catalyst should be able to produce ammonia continuously following these two reactions. However, the catalytic activity test highlights that the continuous ammonia formation was stopped within 150 h. Other than Co sintering which is identified as a possible reason for the catalyst deactivation in the previous section, the continuous formation of LiNH2 should be also investigated as another reason for catalyst instability. Both the ammonia desorption from LiNH2 (R2) and ammonia formation from LiNH2 (reverse-R3) have high enthalpies. Consequently, these reactions require more energy and are expected to proceed slowly at low temperatures. Furthermore, the decomposition of LiNH2 is size-sensitive, necessitating elevated temperatures to facilitate the release of ammonia for a small growth in LiNH2 particle size. Thus, there is a possibility that LiNH2 could accumulate in the catalyst bed while producing ammonia by decomposing or hydrogenation at a slower rate. The accumulation and slower release of LiNH2 could impede the uninterrupted production of ammonia. Besides, LiNH2 can react with LiH (R1), in which the reaction products (Li2NH and H2) do not necessarily lead to produce ammonia at the ammonia synthesis condition [63]. Overall, R1 is more favorable than R2 as the enthalpy of the reaction is smaller. Hence, another scenario of piled-up Li2NH emerged that could ultimately take the reaction to the dead-end as mentioned earlier. A scheme showing the catalyst deactivation steps has been added as Scheme 1. At the start of the ammonia synthesis reaction, the catalyst particles are small and possess a high surface area (c.f. Table 1), eventually facilitating the Li2NH/LiNH2 generation at a higher rate due to the reduced activation energy induced by small catalyst particles [68,69]. This leads to a higher synthesis rate of ammonia initially. As the catalyst particles start agglomerating, they likely lose active surface area (c.f. Table 1). Larger particles dramatically affect the activation energy of several reactions, such as Li2NH/LiNH2 formation (R1 and R3 respectively, and presented as Li-N-H in Scheme 1), thus, hindering those components from proceeding at a reasonable rate for continuous ammonia synthesis for longer periods. Moreover, LiNH2 decomposition (R2) that supports ammonia generation is a diffusion-limited reaction [70], hence, even if a small amount of NH3 is generated, it gets readily absorbed by LiH due to the fast kinetics of the reaction (R3). Over the course of reaction time, this process of the production and absorption of ammonia in the catalyst might reach equilibrium, eventually resulting in the accumulation of Li-N-H compounds and the complete cessation of ammonia synthesis. The deactivation of the catalyst, therefore, can be attributed largely to the diminishing active surface area because of Co sintering, which hampers the generation of Li2NH-LiNH2 at a reasonable rate, and the generated Li2NH-LiNH2 is accumulated in the catalyst bed which finally limits the overall synthesis rate of ammonia. 4 Conclusion The Co-LiH (rxn) catalyst was synthesized by the existing conventional method and tested for long-time operation in different operating conditions. It was identified that the catalyst was unable to produce ammonia after 150 h. Sintering of the Co metal and the presence of intermediate reactions that absorbed ammonia were established as the spatial reasons for deactivation. However, other potential reasons, such as the presence of oxides and chlorine in the catalyst and poisoning by the reactants should be examined extensively though primary analysis rules out their detrimental effect. A facile synthesis with precursors avoiding chlorine compounds should be sought if chlorine is detected as poisonous to TM-MH catalyst-based ammonia synthesis. Lithium hydride-nitride was reported to be stable in a recent study where the material acted as both an active center and support. Hence, it is imminent to introduce a support material in the catalyst to disperse the active metal as well as to increase the active surface area to maintain continuous operation. coredata.dc:description: An efficient ammonia synthesis catalyst that operates under mild conditions has been a long-cherished goal in heterogeneous catalysis. The challenges associated with low-temperature ammonia synthesis arise from both the activation of inert N2 molecules and the presence of scaling relations between reactant dissociation and intermediate adsorption energies. Transition metals-metal hydride (TM-MH) composite catalysts have shown promise to overcome these challenges as both TM and MH actively participate in the reaction, enabling improved ammonia synthesis rates at lower temperatures (150 ºC). Considering this prospect, two types of Co-LiH catalyst were synthesized by ball-milling of precursors (CoCl2 and LiH- denoted as Co-LiH(rxn)) and pure components (Co and LiH- denoted as Co-LiH(pur)), and their catalytic activity was evaluated at several reaction conditions to investigate the stability for long-term operation. Co-LiH(rxn) was found to deactivate in less than 150 h whereas Co-LiH(pur) displayed a continuous production although the synthesis rate was 3 times lower than the former. Structural characterization techniques, such as XRD, SEM, and TEM were used, and it was found that Co metal in the FCC phase was primarily sintered due to its small particle size in the fresh catalyst. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) test on the spent Co-LiH(rxn) catalyst also displayed an ammonia release profile similar to that of LiNH2 decomposition, which confirms the presence of ammonia in the spent catalyst structure. Hence, another major finding is speculated that irreversible ammonia absorption by LiH at the target ammonia reaction conditions contributes to the deactivation of the catalyst and the formation of intermediate compounds that are required for continuous ammonia generation in this composite catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Unraveling the deactivation mechanism of Co-LiH composite catalyst for ammonia synthesis at milder conditions
